column4: How would I be able to find a RAM-intensive application via CLI? I have almost the entire 2GB of RAM used for just a very small LDAP/NFS server and I can't find what's sucking all the RAM (I try using `top` and having it order it by memory usage, but I can't find anything over 5%)
try "htop"
thats what the #ubuntu is for
Yes, that's what I've been doing in top
any ubuntu question, sure
there's nothing that exceeds 5%
how do you know all the ram is being used
by the memory usage indicated at the top of `top`, or by executing `free -m`
pastebin the output of `free -m`
try replacing it with flash 11
http://paste.ubuntu.com/704740/
thats fine, 795+440 isn't "actually" being used
you can't count buffer and cache as usage
So the cache and buffers being for? The filesystem, or?
for example - my computer: http://paste.ubuntu.com/704741/
but what does it truly mean? :P
even if there's nothing to worry about. :P
it means linux uses ram efficiently
So it's dereferenced and hasn't been reallocated to another process then, correct?
sorta
it keeps the stuff in memory in case its needed
lets say I have a 200MB file, and want to md5sum it
